awd_titl_txt: AitF: Collaborative Research: Fair and Efficient Societal Decision Making via Collaborative Convex Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
YouTube competes with Hollywood as an entertainment channel, and also supplements Hollywood by acting as a distribution mechanism. Twitter has a similar relationship to news media, and Coursera to Universities. But there are no online alternatives for making democratic decisions at large scale as a society. As opposed to building consensus and compromise, public discussion boards often devolve into flame wars when dealing with contentious socio-political issues. This project aims to develop algorithms and platforms for collaborative decision making at scale. These platforms will be deployed in real decision-making processes, resulting in substantial broad impact.

Much of the work will be informed by participatory budgeting, where a group of users collectively produce a budget. Since budgetary constraints can be modeled as convex constraints, the insights from participatory budgeting will then be applied to more general convex decision spaces.

On the algorithmic side, the PIs propose to develop algorithms and mechanisms for consensus that go beyond simple voting. In complex decision spaces, the normal voting methodology of ranking a set of candidates breaks down, and we need new mechanisms. For example, for participatory budgeting, the users might be asked to solve a knapsack problem, providing a complete budget. This leads to exciting directions in incentive compatibility, opinion dynamics, fairness, and convex optimization.  Indeed, the PIs believe that this is the natural next step in the evolution of social choice theory, and would represent a substantial intellectual advance in both algorithms and mechanism design.

On the experimental and evaluation side, this work will take the deliberative polling methodology developed by Co-PI Fishkin, and design tools for extending it to participatory budgeting. This project will also evaluate how deliberative polling can scale to large online communities. This is a natural next step in the evolution of deliberative democracy.

On the deployment side, this project will advance our understanding of how to design interfaces for discussion, collaboration, and voting that lead to genuine deliberation and consensus on complex problems, as opposed to devolving into vitriol like many discussion boards and comment threads.

por.por_cntn:
Modern social choice needs the development of platforms where voters can express preferences individually or collaboratively over complex decision spaces that arise in settings such as deciding city budgets or transportation or housing policy. This project aimed to develop a theory and associated platforms for collective decision making at scale. This involved addressing two interrelated challenges. First, an algorithmic and game-theoretic understanding of voting, deliberation, and opinion dynamics for decision making at scale was needed. Second, an empirical and experimental understanding of different social choice mechanisms for consensus and deliberation in complex problem spaces was required, which could lead to deployments in the field. 

Much of the project was informed by the practical problem of Participatory Budgeting, where voters collectively produce a budget for a city, town, or ward. Since budgetary constraints can be modeled as convex constraints, the algorithmic insights from Participatory Budgeting were applied to social choice in more general convex decision spaces. 

Intellectual Merit: We discuss the research highlights of this project. The project produced new existence and algorithmic results in several areas within computational social choice. First, we modeled group fairness in societal decisions via the classic notion of core from cooperative game theory. We presented the first known existence results for an approximate notion of core that applied with general voter preferences. We specialized these results to Participatory Budgeting and fair data analysis problems such as clustering and classification, presenting computationally efficient algorithms for these cases.

 

A second line of research concerns low-complexity social choice schemes in complex decision spaces. In such low-complexity schemes, voters encounter less cognitive overhead and express preferences over a limited set of options, for instance, comparing two options. In collaboration with the PIs at Stanford, we developed a set of such low-complexity schemes that involved voters either sequentially negotiating with each other, or sequentially comparing a few random alternatives, and showed good performance bounds in a theoretical model, as well as good empirical performance via simulations and experiments. 

 

A final line of research involved analyzing social choice rules that either select a single winner when the voters and candidates are assumed to be embedded in an ambient metric space, and voter rankings of candidates are consistent with metric distances to those candidates. A widely studied conjecture was that there exists a deterministic social choice rule whose social cost (total distance of the voters to the chosen candidate in the ambient space) is always within a factor of three of the social cost of the best candidate had the metric space been known. We presented a new social choice rule that eventually led to a positive resolution to this conjecture. We also showed that many natural social choice rules would not be able to resolve this conjecture, and the new rule was required.

 

Broader Impacts:  In terms of impact in the field, in collaboration with the PIs at Stanford, we built a prototype platform for online deliberation with an automated moderator for social discourse. The automatic moderation is done via AI features, and this platform can scale up to handle many deliberations happening in parallel. This platform has been successfully deployed for several real-world deliberations. We have also partnered with the cities of Durham and Greensboro, NC to implement advertising campaigns for recruiting and increasing representation of various minority demographics in their Participatory Budgeting elections. 

 

On the educational front, in addition to curricular improvements such as developing a new course on Algorithmic Decision Making, we have developed and co-organized workshops at the Simons Institute of Theoretical Computer Science, and the ACM EC conference. We have supervised several graduate and undergraduate students (including female students) as part of this grant. These students have won best thesis awards at Duke, best paper awards at leading conferences, and mentions at the CRA outstanding undergraduate researcher award. We have also supervised high school students leading to published papers in leading conferences.
